summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a landlord who had sub-let his property to some other persons who were not his family members, must be evicted. A writ petition has been filed before the High Court of Uttarakhand at Nainital by the appellant Inam Ahmed challenging the eviction order passed by the Rent Control and Eviction Officer, Dehradun, declaring the suit premises in favour of the respondents No.1 and 2 - landlord as vacant after the death of the appellant's father Rashid Ahmed, who was living in the said premises since 1965. In Tirlok Singh (supra), it was held, that a writ petition filed against an order declaring a vacancy only, was premature, as the order did not affect the rights of the person who challenges that order.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a person who gifted 17.25 standard of land to his son was not entitled to the same under the Ceiling Act. summary: The Supreme Court of India has set aside a lower court's decision to allow Bharat Petroleum Corporation (BPC) to sell its stake in Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Limited (HPCL). The appellant, Bharat Petroleum Corp., had entered into dealership agreements with the landlords under the Madras Tenancy Act, 1921, to lease land on long-term lease and had thereupon constructed petrol pumps that were given to and operated by the dealers appointed by the appellant under the dealership agreements. The Supreme Court of India has ruled in a landmark case that landlords in the State of Tamil Nadu are not entitled to enhancement of rent by the tenants in case they do not want to purchase or pay fair market value of the land.

summary: Appeal from the High Court of Andhra Pradesh. The High Court of Andhra Pradesh has held that the Appellant cannot succeed unless she proves the adoption took place in accordance with the provisions of the Act of 1956. Section 7 of the Adoption Act of 1956 provides as under:- “No adoption shall be valid unless – (i) the person adopting has the capacity, and also the right, to take in adoption, (ii) the person giving in adoption has the capacity to do so; (iii) the person adopted is capable of being taken in adoption; and (iv) the adoption is made in compliance with the other conditions mentioned in this Chapter” 11.

summary: The Kerala High Court has reduced the compensation awarded by the Motor Accident Claims Tribunal to the victim's parents by more than 50%. In this case, the High Court interfered with the award of the Tribunal, on 3 counts, namely (i) contributory negligence; (ii) monthly income of the deceased and (iii) multiplier to be applied. The principle of contributory negligence is not based on the fact that a person was a pillion rider on a motor cycle, but rather on the fact that his very act of riding along with two others, contributed either to the accident or to the impact of the accident upon the victim.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has held that the seat of arbitration under the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 is at New Delhi. summary: The Supreme Court has ruled that the rate of interest payable on a compensation claim under the Employee's Compensation Act, 1923, should not be more than 12% per year. In a landmark case, the Tamil Nadu High Court has ruled that the compensation awarded to the family of a lorry driver who died in a road accident in Kotta town in the state should have been paid on the date of the accident. The amicus curiae of the Supreme Court of India in a case involving a worker who was killed in an accident at work urged the Court to adopt the deeming provision in Explanation II to Section 4(1)(a) of the Kerala Workers' Compensation Act, 1923.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a person who loses a leg in a motor accident can appeal against the High Court's decision to award him compensation. The Supreme Court has held that a man who lost his leg in a road accident should be awarded compensation for loss of future earning based on his 75% permanent physical disability and not the 25% of the whole body assessed by the High Court. The effect of the permanent disability on the actual earning capacity of the claimant is known as the "head of loss of amenities of life".

summary: The Supreme Court of India is hearing two appeals relating to reservations to Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in promotions in the posts of Assistant Engineer (Civil) in Public Works Department, Government of Uttarakhand. The High Court of Uttarakhand held that Section 3(7) of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Reservation in Services) Act, 1994 is unconstitutional and directed that no promotion can be given by the State by taking recourse to Section 3(7) of the 1994 Act. Two petitions have been filed in the Uttarakhand High Court challenging the decision of the State Government to implement reservations in promotion by promoting only members Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in future vacancies to maintain the quota earmarked for the said categories.

summary: A bench of the Supreme Court of India, headed by Justice V Ramasubramanian, has taken up a special leave petition for disposal of a suit for a mandatory injunction (construed by the Trial Court as a suit for specific performance). Here is a brief synopsis of the case: The issue before us was whether the petitioner could indirectly seek specific performance of an agreement of sale, by couching the relief as one for mandatory injunction and paying a fixed court fee as payable in a suit for mandatory injunction, the Trial Court, by a convoluted logic, chose to treat the suit as one for specific performance and permitted the petitioner to pay deficit court fee.

summary: The Supreme Court has issued notice to the State of Himachal Pradesh on an appeal by a man convicted of raping a prosecutrix and sentenced to seven years in jail. The appellant Chaman Lal has been convicted and sentenced to five years in jail by the Himachal Pradesh High Court for raping a prosecutrix (PW1). 4.1 It is submitted that the High Court has clearly erred in reversing the order of acquittal passed by the learned trial Court and has rightly convicted the accused for the offences under Sections 376 and 506 IPC, more particularly when the prosecutrix was suffering from mental disease and as per the medical evidence she was not in a position to understand the good and bad aspect of sexual assault.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a coparcenary formed by a Will should be partitioned in accordance with law. Here is a brief synopsis of the case: A Bench of Justices RV Raveendran and VS Sirpurkar held that a notional partition took place on the death of Moola Gounder in terms of Section 8 of the Succession Act, 1925 and that the property in question was not inherited by his legal heirs in their individual rights but only as the property of a Hindu Undivided Family.

summary: The High Court of Uttar Pradesh has allowed a writ petition by a former managing director of the state-owned Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Ltd (UPPCL) seeking to set aside an order terminating his services on the grounds of irregularities in the selection process. The appellant Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL) had appointed Ram Gopal Gopal as its chairman and managing director on the same day as Shyam Behari Lal was appointed as its chairman and managing director. In Shyam Behari Lal, the High Court held that the termination of his services by the Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL) was lawful on the ground that he had been in service for more than 17 years and that he was not entitled to continue in service.

summary: A retired army officer has been found guilty of causing the death of a soldier and attempting to commit suicide in a firing incident in Bareilly, Uttar Pradesh, in 2004. The Armed Forces Tribunal has set aside the order of the Court Martial and remitted the matter for trial from the stage of Court of Inquiry in exercise of its power under Section 16 of the Armed Forces Tribunal Act, 2007. Rule 180 of the Indian Army's Rules of Courts-martial: “No officer or enlisted person shall be tried by a summary court-martial without reference to the officer empowered to convene a district court-martial or on active service a summary general court-martial for the trial of the alleged offender unless— (a) the offence is one which he can try by a summary court-martial without any reference to that officer; or (b) he considers that there is grave reason for immediate action and such reference cannot be made without detriment to discipline.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has held that the state road transport corporation has devolved the responsibility of payment of compensation to the family of the victim of rash and negligent driving by the bus driver. The Supreme Court of India, in a landmark case, held that an insurance company was not liable to pay compensation to the victims of a bus accident because the bus was under the control of the Jammu and Kashmir State Road Transport Corporation (RSRTC). The meaning of the word ‘owner’ in the Motor Vehicles Act, 1957, has changed considerably since then.

summary: The Supreme Court has held that an insurance company is not liable to pay compensation to a person injured in a road accident if the driving licence of the driver at the time of the accident has expired. The appellant was found to be in breach of the statutory duty of a benevolent legislation, i.e., the Compensation Act and, thus, the appellant was burdened to pay interest as also maximum penalty of 50 per cent. The following is a copy of the judgement of the Supreme Court in Swaran Singh.

summary: The Supreme Court has upheld the conviction of Gangadhar alias Gangaram for possession of cannabis and sentenced him to 10 years in jail. The appellant was made an accused on the basis of the evidence of P.W. 6, who deposed that the appellant and Ghasiram had identified the house as belonging to Gokul Dangi which was corroborated by the panchayat records. Sri Jain is right in the submission that according to normal human prudence, it stands to reason why the appellant who was residing in his new house for the last 15 years would identify his own erstwhile house as that of the accused Gokul Dangi, be a witness to the breaking of the lock and recovery to implicate himself.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has upheld the Disciplinary Authority's decision to dismiss an officer from service for misconduct. summary: The Supreme Court of India has dismissed an appeal against the election of Prime Minister Narendra Modi from the Varanasi parliamentary constituency. The Election Commission issued two notices to the appellant on 30.4.2019 and 1S. 9(2) :For the purpose of sub-section (1), a certificate issued by the Election Commission to the effect that a person having held office under the Government of India or under the Government of a State, has or has not been dismissed for corruption or for disloyalty to the State shall be conclusive proof of that fact; Provided that no certificate to the effect that a person has been dismissed for corruption or for disloyalty to the State shall be issued unless an opportunity of being heard has been given to the said person. summary: The Supreme Court of India has upheld a Tripura State Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission’s order directing a low cost airline to pay a compensation of Rs.51,432/ (Rupees fifty one thousand four hundred and thirty only) within two months failing which to pay the same alongwith interest at the rate of 9% per annum, came to be confirmed. The appellantAirlines had operated a flight from Kolkata to Agartala on 10.1.2017, but the respondents failed to report at the boarding gate as per the Conditions of Carriage (for short, ‘the CoC’), which were binding on all concerned, as expounded by the Branch Manager Indigo Airlines ... vs Kalpana Rani Debbarma on 28 January, 2020 Indian Kanoon - http://indiankanoon.org/doc/12210495 On the plea of the respondents, the District Forum held that the appellantAirlines did not provide any assistance to the respondents at the airport to facilitate them to board the flight.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that the tax levied on lottery tickets is unconstitutional. summary: The Supreme Court of India has dismissed appeals from two separate judgements of the Tamil Nadu High Court, which had held that a decree in a suit was entitled to a declaration of title in respect of half a portion of the suit premises and also to recovery of income from the suit property owned by the Respondent and/or charges for use, enjoyment and occupation. This is an appeal from the judgement and decree dated 22.1.1998 of the Trial Court dismissing a suit brought by the Respondent against the Appellant-Defendant for declaration of title to the suit property and recovery of possession of the suit property. The First Appellate Court passed a fair and just order, holding that the Respondent-plaintiff, being the owner of a portion of the said premises, was entitled to declaration of title in respect of the said portion of the suit property, owned by him, but not to recovery of possession, since the defendant was the Appellant.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that an insurance company should pay compensation to the widow of a man who died in a motor vehicle accident in India in 1998. summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that the employer can withhold the payment of superannuation to an employee who has been found guilty of misconduct, even after his superannuation from service, because of the pendency of the disciplinary proceedings instituted against him. The Division Bench of the High Court in the case of Sri Rabindranath Choubey has held that the respondent retired from service on superannuation and the question of imposing a major penalty removal from service would not arise. 3.1 Learned Senior Advocate appearing on behalf of the appellant has heavily relied upon the decision of this Court in the case of State Bank of India v. Ram Lal Bhaskar, reported in (2011) 10 SCC 249.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a motor vehicle accident victim who had to have part of his leg amputated after being injured in a bus, could not get compensation from the bus owner. The appellant was injured in a motor accident and was awarded a head of compensation of  11,6,700 (8000 x 12 x 18). The Supreme Court of India has made it clear that compensation should be paid to the victims of accident, who are disabled either permanently or temporarily.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled in a landmark case that a court in Delhi alone has jurisdiction to hear a civil case where the plaint was returned holding that the court at Gurgaon lacked territorial jurisdiction. Shri Vikas Swarup, senior counsel appearing for the appellant, submitted that the suit had to proceed de novo on return of the plaint. The High Court of India has set aside the order of the Civil Judge at Gurgaon that in view of clause 16B of the franchise agreement, the Gurgaon court lacked territorial jurisdiction.

summary: In a landmark case, the Supreme Court of India has ruled that the National Co-operative Development Corporation (NCDC) should not have to pay tax on its income from grants and loans it received from the Central Government. The first round was before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal (for short ‘CIT(A)’), Delhi Bench, where the AO held that the appellant-Corporation could claim a deduction of 19,35,950/- on account of the grants it received from the Central Government to State Governments and cooperative societies.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled in a landmark case that an insurance company may not disentitle a claimant if an FIR is lodged immediately after the theft of a vehicle. The Supreme Court of India has ruled that the insurance company is entitled to repudiate the claim of the insured if the intimation about the theft of the vehicle is not given to the insurer immediately. In Sriram General Insurance Co. Ltd., the Supreme Court of India has held that delay in making a claim is not a ground for rejecting the claim.

summary: The Bench of Justice Hemant Gupta of the Madhya Pradesh High Court has issued notice to Yogendra Singh Jadon and his brother Harshvardhan Singh Jadon on a petition filed by the State of Madhya Pradesh against an order passed by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh, quashing the proceedings against them in a corruption case. summary: The Supreme Court of India is hearing an appeal against an order of a High Court deciding a case related to an Armed Forces personnel pending before the High Court. The appellant has challenged the setting up of the Armed Forces Tribunal (AFT) in the Supreme Court on the ground that the Special Appeal filed against the judgment of a single judge to a Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court was not liable to be transferred to the Tribunal. The power of judicial review over legislative action vested in the High Courts under Article 226 and in this Court under Article 32 of the Constitution is an integral and essential feature of the Constitution, constituting part of its basic structure.

summary: The Delhi High Court has ruled that a Motor Accident Claims Tribunal should consider the notional income of the deceased as well as the expenses of the minor child in deciding compensation claims. The appellants have moved the Supreme Court challenging the lower court's finding of contributory negligence and deduction of 50% towards the notional income of the first deceased and her minor daughter. The Supreme Court of India in a case of Lata Wadhwa (supra) has held that a person who dies prematurely is not entitled to compensation for loss of earning or monetary loss alone.

summary: The High Court of Haryana has upheld the conviction of a woman accused of possessing 6 kilograms 300 grams of opium. The appellant has moved the Supreme Court challenging the conviction of him on the ground that the prosecution failed to comply with the provisions of Section 50 of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act. The first aspect which is highlighted, as already noticed, was the discrepancy brought out in the testimony of the Gazetted Officer, viz., the DSP who was allegedly called in by the ASI when upon being informed about the right under Section 50, the accused demanded compliance of Section 50 and on a telephone message, the DSP arrived at the spot. The next aspect which is highlighted, as already noticed, was the discrepancy brought out in the testimony of the Gazetted Officer, viz., the DSP who was allegedly called in by the ASI when upon being informed about the right under Section 50, the accused demanded compliance of Section 50 and on a telephone message, the DSP arrived at the spot.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has dismissed an appeal filed by a social organisation challenging a decision of the Central Government to declare it as an organisation of a political nature under Section 5 (1) of the Foreign Contribution (Regulation) Act, 2010. The appellant has challenged the validity of the Income Tax Act, 1961. The Foreign Contribution (Regulation) Act, 1976 was enacted to regulate the acceptance and utilisation of foreign contribution or foreign hospitality by certain individuals or associations, with a view to ensuring that Parliamentary institutions, political associations and academic and other voluntary organisations as well as individuals working in the important areas of national life may function in a manner consistent with the values of a sovereign democratic republic the Foreign Contribution (Regulation) Act, 1976 (49 of 1976) was enacted.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has dismissed an appeal against a High Court ruling that a marriage between two consenting adults was a nullity. On or about 14.2.2015, the Appellant filed an application under Section 125 CrPC, seeking maintenance from the Respondent No.1, inter alia, on the ground that the appellant had been married to the Respondent No.1 for more than two years and that the marriage had been solemnized during the pendency of an appeal from the decree of dissolution of the appellant’s marriage with her first husband. This is an appeal against an order of the Family Court, Hyderabad, quashing an application for maintenance filed by the Respondent No.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a secured creditor is entitled to initiate measures under the Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Interest Act (SARFAESI) for enforcement of security interest created on the secured assets. The record reveals that the appellant (L&T Housing Finance Ltd.) vide its sanction letter dated 07th August, 2015 had entered into a credit facility agreement with the respondents (M/s Trishul Developers) for the purpose of funding the development of a residential project in the city of Mumbai. summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up an appeal against an order of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, Jodhpur, which had upheld the computation of total income of the assessee-appellant for the assessment year 2005-2006, for failure to deduct the requisite tax at source. The appellant firm had hired a number of trucks from different parts of India for transportation of goods of the appellant. The Assessment Officer (AO) of the Income Tax Department, Kanoia, examined the details of the assessee-appellant's receipt for payment to the truck operator/owner of the appellant's vehicle.

summary: The Madhya Pradesh Housing and Infrastructure Development Board has moved the Supreme Court challenging a High Court ruling which had ruled that the layout plan of a residential colony in Ujjain was not approved by the Town and Country Planning (T&CP) department. The appellant-board had changed the layout plan of its residential scheme from a plot facing public amenities like parks, roads, water body, shopping complex to a plot facing public amenities like schools, hospitals, community centres, shopping complex. summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a juvenile accused of a heinous offence should be tried as an adult. In a landmark case, the Supreme Court of India had held that the age of juvenility should not be fixed at too low an age level, saying, “The age of juvenility should not be fixed at too low an age level, bearing in mind the facts of emotional, mental and intellectual maturity. The Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 came into force on 1 January, 2016

summary: The following is a summary of the case heard by the Supreme Court of India on 15 December, 2020. The Competition Commission of India (CCI) has found Ola and Uber guilty of indulging in anti-competitive practices in the taxi-hailing sector. The Competition Commission of India ( Commission) in its order dated 15 December, 2020 has rejected the allegations of cartelisation made by the Informant in the case of Ola and Uber, saying: “The Commission is of the view that no case of contravention of the provisions of Section 3 has been made out and the matter is accordingly closed herewith.”
